questions.text: Which of the following deficiency causes xerophthalmia and follicular hyperkeratosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

Explanation:

 

Vitamin A deficiency is well known to cause a range of clinical manifestations, primarily affecting the eyes and skin. Key signs and symptoms include:

 

  • Xerophthalmia: This condition includes dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea, which can progress to keratomalacia and lead to blindness if untreated.

 

 

  • Follicular hyperkeratosis: This is characterized by excessive keratin deposits in hair follicles, leading to rough, bumpy skin.

 

 

Vitamin A is crucial for maintaining healthy vision, immune function, and skin integrity. Its deficiency can result in:

 

  • Night blindness
  • Immunosuppression: Leading to increased susceptibility to infections.
  • Skin ulceration and corneal ulceration
  • Atrophy of urinary and respiratory tract epithelium, increasing the risk of infections in these areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niacin: Deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.

 

Option C. Biotin: Deficiency can cause dermatitis, alopecia, and neurological symptoms.

 

Option D. Vitamin B6: Deficiency can cause anemia, dermatitis, and neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is likely to aggregate on the surface of a globular protein circulating in the plasma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lysine

 

Explanation:

 

Lysine is a hydrophilic (polar) amino acid with a positively charged side chain. In an aqueous environment like plasma, polar and charged amino acids, such as lysine, preferentially locate on the surface of globular proteins. This positioning allows them to interact with the surrounding water molecules through hydrogen bonds and ionic interactions, stabilizing the protein's structure. Conversely, hydrophobic (nonpolar) amino acids tend to be buried in the interior of the protein to avoid contact with water.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leucine: Leucine is a hydrophobic (nonpolar) amino acid and would typically be found in the interior of a globular protein.

 

Option C. Isoleucine: Isoleucine is also hydrophobic and prefers to reside in the protein's core rather than its surface.

 

Option D. Valine: Valine is another hydrophobic amino acid, favoring the protein's interior over the aqueous environment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lysine, a hydrophilic and positively charged amino acid, is likely to be found on the surface of globular proteins in aqueous solutions like plasma.

questions.text: Mitochondrial matrix enzyme is? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Citrate synthase

 

Citrate synthase is an enzyme located in the mitochondrial matrix, where it catalyzes the first step of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle, also known as the Krebs cycle. This step involves the condensation of oxaloacetate and acetyl-CoA to form citrate. The TCA cycle is a central metabolic pathway that plays a critical role in cellular respiration, generating energy through the oxidation of acetyl-CoA derived from carbohydrates, fats, and proteins.

 

 

Note ‚Äì all the enzymes of TCA are in mitochondrial matrix except ‚Äì Succinate dehydrogenase (present in inner mitochondrial membrane)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Monoamine oxidase: This enzyme is involved in the catabolism of monoamine neurotransmitters such as dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin. It is located on the outer mitochondrial membrane, not in the mitochondrial matrix.

 

Option C. ATP synthase: This enzyme complex is embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane and is responsible for synthesizing ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphate during oxidative phosphorylation. It is part of the electron transport chain (ETC) as Complex V.

 

Option D. Catalase: Catalase is an enzyme that catalyzes the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. It is predominantly found in peroxisomes, not in the mitochondria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Citrate synthase is a key enzyme of the TCA cycle located in the mitochondrial matrix.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is due to which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Peroxisomes

 

Zellweger syndrome, also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome, is a genetic disorder characterized by the absence or malfunction of peroxisomes in cells. Peroxisomes are vital cellular organelles involved in several key metabolic processes, including the beta-oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) and the alpha-oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids. In Zellweger syndrome, there is a mutation in the PEX genes responsible for the biogenesis and function of peroxisomes. This mutation leads to the absence of functional peroxisomes, resulting in the accumulation of VLCFAs and branched-chain fatty acids in the body, which can cause severe developmental abnormalities, particularly in the brain, liver, and kidneys. This includes developmental delay, intellectual disability, frontal bossing, mongoloid face (Down‚Äôs syndrome)

 

Note ‚Äì

 

Refsum disease involves a deficiency in phytanoyl-CoA hydroxylase, which is crucial for the metabolism of branched-chain fatty acids, leading to its accumulation. The clinical manifestations includes retinitis pigmentosa, ichthyosis, and cardiac arrhythmia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nucleosomes: Nucleosomes are the basic units of DNA packaging in eukaryotic cells, consisting of a segment of DNA wound around histone proteins. They are not related to Zellweger syndrome or its pathogenesis.

 

Option C. Lysosomes: Lysosomes are cellular organelles containing digestive enzymes that break down waste materials and cellular debris. While lysosomal storage disorders exist, they are not related to Zellweger syndrome, which is specifically a peroxisomal disorder.

 

Option D. Ribosomes: Ribosomes are the cellular organelles responsible for protein synthesis. They are not implicated in Zellweger syndrome, which is associated with defective peroxisomal function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome is caused by a defect in peroxisomes, leading to the accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids and branched-chain fatty acids, which are not properly metabolized due to the lack of functional peroxisomes.

questions.text: Composition of lactulose: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactose + Fructose

 

Lactulose is a synthetic disaccharide composed of the monosaccharides galactose and fructose. The name "lactulose" suggests its relation to lactose, which is composed of glucose and galactose. However, the "ulose" suffix indicates the presence of a ketone group, identifying fructose as the other component.

 

Lactulose is particularly significant in medicine for its role in treating constipation and hepatic encephalopathy. It is not digested in the small intestine and in large intestine its fermented by intestinal bacteria, producing an acidic pH. This helps in trapping ammonia in the gut by converting it to ammonium ions, which are not reabsorbed, thus aiding in the management of hepatic encephalopathy. Additionally, lactulose creates an osmotic gradient that softens stool, making it effective for treating constipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose + Galactose: This option describes the composition of lactose, not lactulose. Lactose is a naturally occurring disaccharide found in milk and dairy products.

 

Option B. Glucose + Fructose: This combination forms sucrose, commonly known as table sugar, and is not related to lactulose.

 

Option D. Fructose + Ribulose: This combination does not form any common disaccharide relevant to this context, making it incorrect for lactulose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sucrose = Glucose + Fructose
  • Trehalose = Glucose + Glucose
  • Maltose = Glucose + Glucose
  • Lactose = Glucose + Galactose
  • Lactulose = Galactose + Fructose

questions.text: Entry of glucose is insulin independent in all of them except: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Adipose tissues

 

Glucose enters cells through GLUT (glucose transporter) proteins. Some are insulin-dependent, while others are not.

 

Adipose tissues:
‚Ä¢    Use GLUT4
‚Ä¢    Insulin-dependent
‚Ä¢    Insulin stimulates translocation of GLUT4 to membrane ‚Üí increases glucose uptake

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. RBC (Red Blood Cells)
‚Ä¢    Use GLUT1
‚Ä¢    Insulin-independent

 

Option B. Pancreas (Œ≤-cells)
‚Ä¢    Use GLUT2
‚Ä¢    Insulin-independent
‚Ä¢    Glucose entry triggers insulin secretion

 

Option D. Brain
‚Ä¢    Uses GLUT1 (BBB) and GLUT3 (neurons)
‚Ä¢    Both are insulin-independent
‚Ä¢    Brain requires a constant glucose supply regardless of insulin


 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Methyl tetrahydrofolate accumulation and functional deficiency of folate is seen in the deficiency of: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vit B12

 

Vitamin B12, also known as cobalamin, is essential for DNA synthesis and plays a role in the conversion of methyl tetrahydrofolate to its active form. Deficiency of vitamin B12 can lead to the functional deficiency of folate because it impairs the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from methyl tetrahydrofolate, leading to the accumulation of the latter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folic acid: Folic acid, also known as vitamin B9, is a crucial vitamin required for DNA synthesis, cell division, and various metabolic processes. In cases of folic acid deficiency, methyl tetrahydrofolate can accumulate, but there is no direct deficiency of vitamin B12. Folic acid deficiency primarily affects folate-dependent reactions.

 

Option C. Vit B1: Vitamin B1, also known as thiamine, is not directly related to the metabolism of folate or methyl tetrahydrofolate. It primarily plays a role in carbohydrate metabolism as a cofactor for enzymes involved in the citric acid cycle.

 

Option D. Vit B6: Vitamin B6, also known as pyridoxine, is involved in various enzymatic reactions, including those related to amino acid metabolism. It is not directly associated with the metabolism of folate or methyl tetrahydrofolate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the metabolic consequences of vitamin deficiencies, medical students should recognize that the functional deficiency of folate, characterized by the accumulation of methyl tetrahydrofolate, is primarily seen in vitamin B12 deficiency, making it important to distinguish between the two deficiencies in clinical practice.

 

Deficiency of Vitamin B12 leads to accumulation of methyl THF. Free THF becomes deficient (Folate Trap) and as THF is functional form of folate it is also known as functional deficiency of folate.

 

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 536

questions.text: Chimeric DNA is used for? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Organ transplantation

 

Chimeric DNA (also known a recombinant DNA) is used in organ transplantation, especially in bone marrow transplant. It allows for the production of essential therapeutic proteins and other biological products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paternity test:

  • Function: Uses genetic markers to determine biological parentage.
  • Relevance: Typically uses DNA fingerprinting rather than chimeric DNA technology.

 

Option B. Maternity test:

  • Function: Similar to paternity testing, using genetic markers for parentage.
  • Relevance: Uses DNA fingerprinting, not chimeric DNA.

 

Option C. Personal identification:

  • Function: Uses DNA profiling for forensic and legal identification.
  • Relevance: DNA fingerprinting and STR analysis are common methods, not chimeric DNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uses of Chimeric DNA are:

 

  1. Recombinant human insulin
  2. Recombinant human growth hormone (HGH, somatotropin) and other human hormones (e.g. FSH)
  3. Recombinant blood clotting factor VIII and other clotting factors (Factor IX, tPA, hirudin)
  4. Recombinant hepatitis B vaccine, HPV vaccine, etc.
  5. Cytokines and growth factors (interferon, interleukins, etc.)
  6. Monoclonal antibodies and other related products (rituximab, trastuzumab, etc.)
  7. Recombinant enzymes (acid Œ± glucosidase [myozyme], Œ± L iduronidase [aldurazyme])
  8. Recombinant HIV protein for HIV ELISA testing
  9. Herbicide and insect resistant crops
  10. Other products: Bone morphogenic protein (BMP), albumin, fibinolytic and thrombolytic agents, etc.
  11. Gene mapping using techniques such as fluorescence in sit hybridization (FISH).
  12. Molecular analysis of disease, to detect gene variations and mutations.
  13. Restriction Fragment Length polymorphism (RFLP) and single nucleotide polymorphism (SN)
  14. Microsatellite DNA polymorphisms
  15. Gene therapy and bone marrow transplantation

questions.text: Which of the following types of collagens is involved in wound healing? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type III

 

Collagen III is the first to be synthesized in the early stages of wound healing and is replaced by collagen I, the dominant skin collagen. Initially there is random deposition of collagen during the granulation tissue formation which is further enhanced by enzyme-induced covalent cross-linking. This process matures the collagen into complex structures that are reoriented for tensile strength restoration. Collagen remodeling continues for months after wound closure and the tensile strength of the repaired tissue increases to about 80‚Äì85% of normal tissue if all processes proceed without any perturbations.

 

Note ‚Äì

  • Collagen is a major structural protein found in connective tissue.

 

  • Type I is the most abundant form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type II:

  • Location: Found primarily in cartilage and the vitreous humor of the eye.
  • Function: Provides structural support to cartilage and vitreous body.
  • Disease: Deficiency leads to severe chondrodysplasias and osteoarthritis.

 

Option C. Type IV:

  • Location: Found in basement membranes.
  • Function: Provides structural integrity to the basement membrane.
  • Disease: Deficiency causes Alport syndrome.

 

Option D. Type V:

  • Location: Found as a minor component in tissues containing collagen I.
  • Function: Contributes to the regulation of collagen fibril assembly.
  • Disease: Deficiency causes Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type I (EDS-I).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Properties of Different types of Collagen:

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with phenylketonuria with normal phenylalanine hydroxylase levels? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dihydrobiopterin reductase

 

Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a genetic disorder where phenylalanine, an essential amino acid, cannot be properly metabolized due to enzyme deficiencies. In classical PKU, the deficiency is in phenylalanine hydroxylase, which converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. However, if phenylalanine hydroxylase levels are normal, as stated in the question, the problem lies elsewhere in the metabolic pathway. Dihydrobiopterin reductase is an enzyme that regenerates tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor necessary for phenylalanine hydroxylase function. If dihydrobiopterin reductase is deficient, tetrahydrobiopterin cannot be regenerated, leading to non-classical PKU despite normal phenylalanine hydroxylase levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tyrosine transaminase: This enzyme is involved in the catabolism of tyrosine, not in the initial conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine or the regeneration of tetrahydrobiopterin, making it unrelated to PKU.

 

Option C. Dopa decarboxylase: This enzyme is involved in the synthesis of neurotransmitters like dopamine from DOPA, unrelated to phenylalanine metabolism or PKU.

 

Option D. Tyrosine hydroxylase: This enzyme converts tyrosine to DOPA and is involved in neurotransmitter synthesis, not in phenylalanine metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In non-classical phenylketonuria, the deficiency is in dihydrobiopterin reductase, not phenylalanine hydroxylase.

questions.text: PCR is used to detect all of the following except? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aneuploidy

 

Standard PCR techniques cannot directly detect aneuploidy (changes in chromosome number) as they can only measure relative amounts of DNA and cannot distinguish between presence of extra chromosomes or loss of chromosomes. Aneuploidy detection requires techniques that can analyze whole chromosome numbers like FISH, karyotyping, or specialized methods like QF-PCR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Single nucleotide polymorphisms: PCR, especially when combined with techniques like RFLP or sequencing, is excellent for detecting SNPs. Methods like allele-specific PCR can specifically amplify and detect single base changes.

 

Option B. Microdeletions: PCR can detect small deletions through techniques like multiplex PCR or quantitative PCR, which can identify missing sequences by comparing amplification patterns.

 

Option C. Chromosomal translocations: PCR can detect specific translocation breakpoints using primers that span the fusion points, commonly used in detecting cancer-associated translocations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While PCR is highly sensitive for sequence-level changes (SNPs, small deletions) and specific chromosomal breakpoints, it cannot directly detect numerical chromosomal abnormalities (aneuploidy) without specialized modifications. This highlights the importance of choosing appropriate molecular techniques based on the type of genetic alteration being investigated.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is necessary for conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Methionine

 

Methionine is involved in the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine. It donate methyl group in the form of SAM.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine: It is the precursor amino acid for the synthesis of both norepinephrine and epinephrine in the catecholamine biosynthetic pathway. But it is not directly involved in their intercomversion,

 

Option B. Tryptophan: Tryptophan is not directly involved in the synthesis of norepinephrine or epinephrine. Tryptophan is an essential amino acid and serves as the precursor for serotonin, melatonin, and niacin (vitamin B3).

 

Option C. Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine is not directly involved in the synthesis of norepinephrine or epinephrine. It is an essential amino acid and serves as the precursor for tyrosine through the action of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methionine is necessary for the conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine.

 

Norepinephrine is methylated by the enzyme N-methyl transferase (NMT) to epinephrine or adrenaline.

 

S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) is the methyl donor. It is mainly produced by adrenal medulla and adrenergic nerve endings. It is stored in chromaffin granules and released into blood.

choices.text: It is involved in the creation of Okazaki fragments
It is the primary enzyme of DNA synthesis

questions.text: Which of the following is true about DNA polymerase I? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is found in prokaryotes

 

This statement is correct. DNA polymerase I is primarily found in prokaryotic organisms, including bacteria. In prokaryotes, it plays a crucial role in DNA replication and repair.

 

Additional Information ‚Äì

 

DNA polymerase I (Kornberg‚Äôs enzyme) from Escherichia coli (prokaryote). It is a repair  enzyme. It has both 3‚Ä≤ to 5‚Ä≤ and 5‚Ä≤ to 3‚Ä≤ exonuclease activities. When 5‚Ä≤ to 3‚Ä≤ exonuclease domain is removed, the remaining fragment retains the polymerization and proofreading activities; it is then called Klenow fragment. It is widely used in recombinant DNA technology.

 

DNA polymerases I, II, and III are prokaryotic polymerases.

 

DNA polymerase II: DNA proofreading and repair.

 

DNA polymerase III: Main replication enzyme in bacteria

 

In mammalian cells (eukaryotic), there are 5 DNA polymerases (DNAPs) named as Œ±, Œ≤, Œ≥, Œ¥ and Œµ.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is involved in the creation of Okazaki fragments: DNA polymerase I main function is to remove RNA primers from Okazaki fragments and fill the gaps with DNA nucleotides. The synthesis of Okazaki fragments is primarily carried out by DNA polymerase III in prokaryotes.

 

Option C. It synthesizes RNA primers: DNA polymerase I does not synthesize RNA primers. Instead, it removes RNA primers by its 5' to 3' exonuclease activity as part of the primer removal process during DNA replication.

 

Option D. It is the primary enzyme of DNA synthesis: This statement is not true. While DNA polymerase I is involved in DNA replication, it is not the primary enzyme responsible for DNA synthesis. In prokaryotes, DNA polymerase III is the primary enzyme responsible for DNA synthesis during replication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA polymerase I is a critical enzyme found in prokaryotes, involved in DNA replication and repair. While it plays key roles, including the removal of RNA primers from Okazaki fragments, DNA polymerase III is the primary enzyme for DNA synthesis in these organisms

questions.text: The anterior incisors of a child with white patches turned brown following over supplementation of: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluorine in water

 

Explanation:

 

The description of white patches turning brown on the anterior incisors of a child is indicative of dental fluorosis. This condition occurs due to excessive fluoride intake, particularly during the years when teeth are developing. Fluoride is beneficial in small amounts for dental health, but excessive exposure, often due to high levels in drinking water or overuse of fluoride supplements, can lead to fluorosis, which manifests as mottling and discoloration of teeth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlorine in Water: While chlorine is used to purify water, it does not cause dental fluorosis, which is characterized by changes in the color and structure of teeth. Chlorine at levels used in water treatment does not typically result in dental discoloration.

 

Option C. Vitamin A: While excessive Vitamin A intake can lead to toxicity with a variety of symptoms, it does not cause dental fluorosis. Vitamin A toxicity typically presents with symptoms such as skin changes, vision disturbances, and bone pain, but not with changes in tooth color.

 

Option D. Riboflavin: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) is not associated with dental discoloration. Deficiency of riboflavin can lead to mouth and lip sores, but its excess does not result in changes similar to fluorosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fluoride prevents caries, as topical application of fluoride will result in a fluorapatite layer on the enamel, which protects enamel from the decay by acid.
  • The safe limit of fluorine is about 1 ppm in water.
  • Fluoride level >>2 ppm causes chronic intestinal upset, gastroenteritis, loss of appetite and loss of weight.
  • Level >>5 ppm causes mottling of enamel, stratification and discoloration of teeth.
  • A level >>>20 ppm is toxic and causes alternate areas of osteoporosis and osteosclerosis with brittle bones known as fluorosis.

 

Ref: Textbook of Medical biochemistry 3rd edition Page no. 416

questions.text: Which enzyme is deficient in Von Gierke‚Äôs disease:(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucose-6-phosphatase

 

Explanation:

 

Von Gierke‚Äôs disease, also known as Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (GSD I), is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase. This enzyme is crucial for the final step in the gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis pathways, where it catalyzes the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate into glucose, which is then released into the bloodstream. Its deficiency leads to impaired glucose production and subsequent hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branching Enzyme: A deficiency in the branching enzyme is associated with Glycogen Storage Disease Type IV (Andersen‚Äôs disease), not Von Gierke‚Äôs disease. This enzyme is responsible for adding branches to the growing glycogen molecule, and its deficiency leads to abnormal glycogen structure.

 

Option C. Debranching Enzyme: A deficiency in the debranching enzyme characterizes Glycogen Storage Disease Type III (Cori‚Äôs disease), not Von Gierke‚Äôs disease. This enzyme is involved in the breakdown of glycogen, particularly in removing the branches from glycogen during glycogenolysis.

 

Option D. Myophosphorylase: Myophosphorylase deficiency is seen in Glycogen Storage Disease Type V (McArdle‚Äôs disease). This enzyme is involved in glycogen breakdown in muscle tissue, and its deficiency leads to muscle-related symptoms, especially during exercise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Gierke‚Äôs disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I) is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase, leading to impaired glucose production from gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, and resulting in hypoglycemia.

 

C/F of this disease includes glycogen accumulation in liver and renal tubule cells, hypoglycaemia, lactic academia, ketosis and hyperlipidemia.

 

Ref: Harper‚Äôs Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 174

questions.text: A patient has liver damage. His eyes examination showed the given picture. Patient also had neurological manifestations. Which factor is responsible for his disease? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Copper

 

Explanation:

 

The described clinical picture is highly suggestive of Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder of copper metabolism. In Wilson's disease, there is an accumulation of copper in various tissues, including the liver and brain, leading to liver damage and neurological symptoms. The eye examination often reveals Kayser-Fleischer rings, a characteristic sign involving copper deposition in the cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Galactose: While disorders in galactose metabolism, such as galactosemia, can cause liver damage, they do not typically present with the specific eye findings or the same neurological manifestations described in the scenario. Galactosemia usually presents in infancy with symptoms like oil drop cataract,  failure to thrive, jaundice, and feeding difficulties.

 

Option C. Mannose: Mannose metabolism disorders are rare and do not typically present with liver damage, neurological symptoms, and eye changes as described. These disorders often have different clinical manifestations, including developmental delay and immune dysfunction.

 

Option D. Glucose: While diabetes (a disorder of glucose metabolism) can lead to liver damage and may have ocular manifestations (like diabetic retinopathy), it does not typically present with Kayser-Fleischer rings or the described neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kayser-Fleischer ring shown in the image occurs in Wilson disease.
  • This disease is caused by mutations in a copper-binding ATPase which leads to copper storage in the eye (Kayser-Fleischer ring), liver (hepatitis and cirrhosis) and brain (psychosis).

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Long chain fatty acid

 

Zellweger syndrome is due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA). Peroxisomal enzymes are produced; but their entry into peroxisome is denied. This leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA. Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes neurological impairment and death in childhood.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose: Accumulation of glucose is associated with disorders like diabetes, not Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option B. Lactic acid: Accumulation of lactic acid is seen in lactic acidosis and mitochondrial disorders, but not specifically in Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Triglycerides: While triglycerides are stored fats, their accumulation is not the primary issue in Zellweger syndrome. The critical problem is the accumulation of VLCFA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome leads to the accumulation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) in the brain due to defective peroxisomal oxidation, resulting in severe neurological impairments and early childhood death.

questions.text: The significance of HMP shunt are all except? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Utilizes ribose

 

Explanation:

 

The Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP), has several significant roles:

 

Option A. Source of NADPH: The HMP shunt produces NADPH in its oxidative phase. NADPH is essential for various biosynthetic reactions, including fatty acid synthesis and maintaining the reduced state of glutathione in red blood cells.

 

Option B. Source of ribose 5 phosphate: At the end of the oxidative phase, ribulose 5-phosphate is produced, which can be further converted into ribose 5-phosphate. Ribose 5-phosphate is a crucial precursor for the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleic acids.

 

Option C. Source of acetyl CoA: One of the end products of the HMP shunt is glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate, which can enter glycolysis. Through glycolysis, it can eventually form pyruvate, which can be converted into acetyl CoA in the presence of oxygen.

 

Option D. Utilizes ribose: This statement is incorrect as the HMP shunt primarily produces ribose 5-phosphate rather than utilizing it. Ribose 5-phosphate is a significant product of this pathway and is used in the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleic acids.

 

The overall reaction of the HMP shunt can be summarized as:

 

3G-6-P+6NADP+‚Üí2G-6-P+Glyceraldehyde-3-P+3CO2+6NADPH

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HMP shunt is significant for producing NADPH and ribose 5-phosphate and indirectly contributing to the formation of acetyl CoA, but it does not utilize ribose.

questions.text: Complex 4 inhibitor is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyanide

 

Explanation:


Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) in the electron transport chain (ETC). Complex IV is crucial for the final step of the electron transport chain, where it facilitates the transfer of electrons to oxygen, the final electron acceptor, to form water. By inhibiting Complex IV, cyanide prevents the reduction of oxygen, halting ATP production and leading to cellular hypoxia and energy failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbon Dioxide: Carbon dioxide is not an inhibitor of any of the electron transport chain complexes. It is a byproduct of cellular respiration and does not interfere with the function of the ETC complexes.

 

Option C. Oligomycin: Oligomycin is an inhibitor of ATP synthase (Complex V) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the F0 subunit of ATP synthase, blocking the proton channel and preventing proton translocation across the inner mitochondrial membrane. This inhibition halts ATP synthesis from ADP and inorganic phosphate.

 

Option D. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the Qi site of cytochrome c reductase, blocking the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, disrupting the proton gradient and halting ATP synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibitor of ETC complexes

 

 

Reference: Harper‚Äôs 31st ed/pg- 123

questions.text: Klenow fragment lacks the activity of? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B)  5‚Äô‚Üí 3‚Äô Exonuclease

 

DNA polymerase I (Kornberg‚Äôs enzyme) was isolated from Escherichia coli. It is a repair enzyme. It has both 3‚Äô to 5‚Äô and 5‚Äô to 3‚Äô exonuclease activities. When 5‚Äô to 3‚Äô exonuclease domain is removed, the remaining fragment retains the polymerization and proofreading activities; it is then called Klenow fragment. It is widely used in recombinant DNA technology.

 

The Klenow fragment retains the polymerization (5' ‚Üí 3' DNA polymerase) and proofreading (3' ‚Üí 5' exonuclease) activities but lacks the 5' ‚Üí 3' exonuclease activity. Because of these retained activities, the Klenow fragment is widely used in recombinant DNA technology for applications that require DNA synthesis and proofreading without the degradation of the DNA template.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3' ‚Üí 5' Exonuclease: The Klenow fragment retains this activity, which allows it to proofread and correct errors during DNA synthesis.

 

Option C. 5' ‚Üí 3' DNA polymerase: The Klenow fragment retains this activity, which is essential for synthesizing new DNA strands.

 

Option D. 3' ‚Üí 5' DNA polymerase: This activity is not applicable in the context of DNA polymerase I and the Klenow fragment, as DNA polymerase functions in the 5' ‚Üí 3' direction for synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase I retains the 5' ‚Üí 3' DNA polymerase and 3' ‚Üí 5' exonuclease (proofreading) activities but lacks the 5' ‚Üí 3' exonuclease activity, making it useful for specific applications in recombinant DNA technology.

questions.text: Inhibitor A and B are: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Competitive and non-competitive

 

Inhibitor A is a competitive inhibitor, and Inhibitor B is a non-competitive inhibitor.

 

  • Competitive Inhibition (Inhibitor A): In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme. This means that increasing the concentration of the substrate can overcome the inhibition. In this scenario, the maximum velocity (Vmax) of the reaction remains unchanged because, at high substrate concentrations, the enzyme can still achieve its maximum rate. However, the apparent affinity of the enzyme for the substrate decreases, leading to an increase in the Michaelis constant (Km). On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, competitive inhibition is indicated by lines that intersect on the y-axis, which represents no change in Vmax but a change in Km.
  • Non-Competitive Inhibition (Inhibitor B): Non-competitive inhibitors bind to an allosteric site rather than the active site, and their binding is not affected by the substrate concentration. As a result, the inhibition cannot be overcome by adding more substrate. Non-competitive inhibition leads to a decrease in the Vmax because the inhibitor reduces the overall number of active enzymes. However, Km remains unchanged because the binding of the inhibitor does not affect the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate. On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, non-competitive inhibition is indicated by lines that intersect on the x-axis, reflecting no change in Km but a decrease in Vmax.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uncompetitive and non-competitive: Uncompetitive inhibitors bind only to the enzyme-substrate complex, not to the free enzyme. This binding decreases both Km and Vmax because the inhibitor effectively removes some enzyme-substrate complexes from the reaction. This option is incorrect because Inhibitor A shows characteristics of competitive inhibition, not uncompetitive inhibition.

 

Option C. Non-competitive and uncompetitive: This option is incorrect because Inhibitor A is competitive, not non-competitive, and Inhibitor B is non-competitive, not uncompetitive. Therefore, this combination does not accurately represent the inhibition types for Inhibitor A and B.

 

Option D. Non-competitive and competitive: This option is incorrect because it reverses the correct inhibition types for Inhibitor A and B. Inhibitor A is competitive, while Inhibitor B is non-competitive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remember that competitive inhibitors increase Km but do not change Vmax, while non-competitive inhibitors decrease Vmax but do not change Km.

questions.text: A farmer is on a maize-based diet and develops skin rashes on the face, neck, and hand. Which of the following should be given? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

The farmer‚Äôs symptoms of skin rashes in sun-exposed areas like the face, neck, and hands are characteristic of pellagra, a condition caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. Maize-based diets are deficient in tryptophan, which is necessary for niacin synthesis in the body. Pellagra is characterized by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, with the dermatitis presenting as symmetrical, pigmented, and scaly skin rashes. Providing niacin supplementation is the appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency causes beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, not pellagra. The symptoms of thiamine deficiency are primarily neurological and cardiovascular, not dermatological.

 

Option C. Retinol: Retinol (vitamin A) deficiency leads to visual problems, including night blindness and xerophthalmia, and does not cause skin rashes typical of pellagra.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to anemia and neurological symptoms, including neuropathy and cognitive disturbances. It does not cause skin rashes or dermatitis associated with niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin deficiency in individuals consuming a maize-based diet can lead to pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Niacin supplementation is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: dd-NTPs in Sanger‚Äôs Sequencing technique uses? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Termination of polymerase

 

  • The correct answer is C. ddNTPs are used in Sanger's Sequencing because they lack the 3'-OH group required for the formation of the phosphodiester bond during DNA strand elongation. When a ddNTP is incorporated into the growing DNA strand by DNA polymerase, it causes termination of DNA synthesis because the next nucleotide cannot be added due to the absence of the 3'-OH group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Its fluorescence: ddNTPs in Sanger's Sequencing are not primarily used for their fluorescence. While modern Sanger Sequencing methods may incorporate fluorescence for detection, ddNTPs themselves are not inherently fluorescent.

 

Option B. DNA polymerization: ddNTPs do not contribute to DNA polymerization in the same way as regular dNTPs (deoxynucleotide triphosphates). Regular dNTPs are used by DNA polymerase to extend the DNA strand, while ddNTPs have a unique property that leads to their specific role in sequencing.

 

Option D. Removal of primer: ddNTPs are not involved in the removal of primers in Sanger's Sequencing. Primer removal typically occurs after the sequencing reaction is complete and is not directly related to the role of ddNTPs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dideoxy nucleotides are nucleotides in which O from 2‚Äô and 3‚Äô position of sugar is absent. These nucleotides, if inserted in the growing DNA chains will cause termination of polymerization as DNA polymerase will not be able to perform catalyzation of formation of Phosphodiester bond. This form the basis for a DNA sequencing technique know as Sanger DNA sequencing aka chain termination method.

 

Reference: Harper‚Äôs 31st ed/pg- 439

questions.text: Glucosamines are used in which of the following conditions? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arthritis

 

Glucosamine and chondroitin sulphate are used in the treatment of arthritis which is a degenerative joint disease.

 

Glucosamines are amino sugars. Mucopolysaccharides or glycosamino glycans (GAG) are heteropolysaccharides, containing uronic acid and amino sugars. Acetylated amino groups, sulfate and carboxyl groups are also generally present. Because of the presence of these charged groups, they attract water molecules and so they produce viscous solutions.

 

Examples of mucopolysaccharides are hyaluronic acid, heparin, chondroitin sulfate, dermatan sulfate and keratan sulfate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niemann-Pick disease: This is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by the accumulation of sphingomyelin, not treated with glucosamines.

 

Option C. Alzheimer's disease: This neurodegenerative condition involves the accumulation of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. Glucosamines are not used in its treatment.

 

Option D. Cancer: Cancer treatment involves a wide range of therapies such as chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and immunotherapy. Glucosamines are not used in cancer treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucosamine is used in the treatment of arthritis due to its role in maintaining healthy cartilage and joint function.

questions.text: A farmer is spraying an odourless chemical in the fields, which is an Inhibitor of Complex III of ETC. Identify the compound: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antimycin A

 

Antimycin A is an inhibitor of Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) of the ETC. It binds to the Qo site of cytochrome b and blocks electron transfer from ubiquinol to cytochrome c1, disrupting ATP synthesis. It's used in fisheries and can be employed in agricultural settings for pest control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carboxin: Carboxin is a fungicide, but it primarily inhibits succinate dehydrogenase (Complex II) in the ETC, not Complex III. It interferes with fungal respiration by inhibiting electron transport at this specific complex.

 

Option B. Rotenone: Rotenone is an insecticide and piscicide that inhibits Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase) of the ETC. It acts by blocking electron transport, leading to the cessation of ATP production in the cells it affects.

 

Option C. Cyanide: Cyanide is a potent and highly toxic compound that inhibits Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) of the ETC. It binds to the iron in the heme group of cytochrome c oxidase, stopping cellular respiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibitors of ETC:

 

Complex I- Rotenone, Phenobarbitone, Amobarbital

 

Complex II- Malonate (3C), Carboxin

 

Complex III- Phenformin, Antimycin A, BAL

 

Complex IV- CN, CO, Sodium azide, H2S

 

Pesticides used in agricultural fields:

 

  • Rotenone is also an insecticide, pesticide and a herbicide
  • Carboxin is a fungicide that is commonly used in agricultural practices
  • Antimycin ‚Äì used in agriculture to control certain pests that affect crops
  • Cyanide

 

Ref: Harper‚Äôs Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 127

questions.text: In a preterm baby with respiratory distress syndrome, which of the following lipid would be deficient?( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl choline

 

This is the correct answer. DPPC is a major component of pulmonary surfactant, and its deficiency in preterm infants is a key factor in the development of RDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is not the deficient lipid in RDS. While it is a component of pulmonary surfactant, the primary deficiency in RDS is of DPPC.

 

L:S (Lecithin: Sphingomyelin) ratio > 2 is an indicator of fetal lung maturity at 32 weeks of gestation.

 

Option B. Cardiolipin: Cardiolipin is not the deficient lipid in RDS. It is found in the inner mitochondrial membrane and is not directly related to pulmonary surfactant.

 

Disease related to Cardiolipins

 

  1. Barth Syndrome: Defect in cardiolipin remodelling
  2. Anti-Phospholipid Syndrome: Occurs due to Anticardiolipin antibodies formed in body. C/f are A thrombotic condition and Disease females has history of recurrent infection

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because, as explained above, DPPC is deficient in preterm babies with RDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RDS occurs when there is not enough surfactant in the lungs. Surfactant is a liquid made by the lungs that keeps the airways (alveoli) open. Pulmonary surfactant is a surface-active lipoprotein complex (phospholipoprotein) formed by type II alveolar cells. The proteins and lipids that make up the surfactant have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions. By adsorbing to the air-water interface of alveoli, with hydrophilic head groups in the water and the hydrophobic tails facing towards the air, the main lipid component of surfactant is dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC).

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed pg ‚Äì 234

choices.text: Short telomere with damaged DNA and loss of helicase

questions.text: Which of the following is the etiology of the Werner syndrome with premature aging?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Short telomere with damaged DNA and loss of helicase

 

This is the correct explanation for the etiology of Werner syndrome. Individuals with Werner syndrome have mutations in the WRN gene, which encodes a helicase enzyme involved in DNA repair and maintenance. These mutations lead to the loss of helicase function and result in the accumulation of DNA damage and shortened telomeres, contributing to premature aging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased length of telomere: This option is not the cause of Werner syndrome. In fact, individuals with Werner syndrome have shortened telomeres, not increased length. Telomeres are the protective caps at the end of chromosomes, and their shortening is associated with aging and age-related diseases.

 

Option C. Increased advanced glycation end products: Advanced glycation end products (AGEs) are associated with various age-related conditions, but they are not the primary cause of Werner syndrome. While AGEs can contribute to cellular damage, they are not the central mechanism behind this syndrome.

 

Option D. Decreased lipid peroxidation: Decreased lipid peroxidation is not the primary cause of Werner syndrome. Lipid peroxidation refers to the oxidative damage to lipids (fats), and although oxidative stress is involved in aging, it is not the primary driver of Werner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Werner syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by premature aging. It is caused by mutations in the WRN gene, which encodes a protein called Werner syndrome ATP-dependent helicase (WRN). The WRN protein is involved in DNA repair, maintenance of genome stability, and telomere maintenance. One of the other functions of this protein is DNA helicase.

 

In Werner syndrome, there is a loss of function of the WRN protein, leading to problems with DNA repair and telomere maintenance. Telomeres are the protective caps at the ends of chromosomes, and they shorten with each cell division. In Werner syndrome, there is accelerated telomere shortening, and this contributes to premature aging. There is also increased risk of cancer.

 

Ref: Harper‚Äôs 31st/e pg. 370

questions.text: Banding technique used for dicentric chromosomes:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

Explanation:

 

Dicentric chromosome is an abnormal chromosome with two centromeres.

 

 

C banding: stains heterochromatin which are regions of the chromosomes at or near centromere. So, C banding will be most useful for dicentric chromosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G-banding: G-banding is the most common banding technique and uses Giemsa stain to stain AT-rich regions. It was developed as an alternative to Q-banding due to the cumbersome nature of Q-banding.

 

Option B. NOR-banding: NOR-banding (Nucleolar Organizer Region) is used to stain regions associated with nucleolus formation and is not specifically useful for dicentric chromosomes.

 

Option D. R-banding: R-banding provides a reverse pattern to G-banding, staining GC-rich regions instead of AT-rich regions. It is not specifically useful for identifying dicentric chromosomes.

 

Note ‚Äì  Q banding: uses quinacrine dye (first used dye) and stains repetitive AT rich regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C-banding is the preferred technique for identifying dicentric chromosomes as it specifically stains heterochromatin regions at or near the centromere.

 

Reference: Robbins 10th Ed. / page- 262-263, 293

questions.text: Vitamin B12 is found maximum in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Animal products

 

Vitamin B12 is most abundant in animal-derived foods such as meat, fish, poultry, eggs, and dairy products. These sources are rich in this essential vitamin, making it an important part of the diets of individuals who consume animal products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Green Leafy Vegetables: Green leafy vegetables, while nutritious and a source of many vitamins and minerals, are generally not a significant source of vitamin B12. In fact, plant-based sources of B12 are limited, and green leafy vegetables are not a reliable source of this vitamin.

 

Option C. Roots and Tubers: Roots and tubers are also not a substantial source of vitamin B12. This vitamin is not typically found in plant-based foods in significant quantities, so relying solely on roots and tubers for B12 would likely result in a deficiency.

 

Option D. Sunlight: Sunlight is not a source of vitamin B12. This vitamin is not synthesized by the body through exposure to sunlight, as is the case with vitamin D.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 is naturally present in foods of animal origin, including fish, meat, poultry, eggs, and dairy products. Hence, vegetarians usually are prone to develop vitamin b12 deficiency. Strict vegetarians (vegans) are at risk of developing B12 deficiency.

choices.text: Human cells can divide a finite number of times only
Free radical oxidation level is unrestricted
RNA polymerase can function for a finite number of times only

questions.text: What is true about the Hayflick limit? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Human cells can divide a finite number of times only

 

Leonard Hayflick discovered that cultured normal human cells have limited capacity to divide, after which they become senescent ‚Äî a phenomenon now known as the ‚ÄòHayflick limit‚Äô.

 

Each time a cell undergoes mitosis, the telomeres on the ends of each chromosome shorten slightly. Cell division will cease once telomeres shorten to a critical length. Hayflick interpreted his discovery to be aging at the cellular level. The aging of cell populations appears to correlate with the overall physical aging of an organism. Normal human fetal cell population will divide between 40 and 60 times in cell culture before entering a senescence phase. However, this limit does not apply to stem cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Free radical oxidation level is unrestricted: Free radical oxidation is related to oxidative stress and damage but is not directly related to the Hayflick limit.

 

Option C. Telomerase activity is unrestricted: In most somatic cells, telomerase activity is limited, leading to telomere shortening. However, certain cells like stem cells and cancer cells exhibit higher telomerase activity, allowing them to bypass the Hayflick limit.

 

Option D. RNA polymerase can function for a finite number of times only: RNA polymerase activity is not directly linked to the Hayflick limit and does not have a finite number of times it can function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hayflick limit describes the finite number of times that normal human cells can divide before they become senescent, primarily due to telomere shortening.

questions.text: Ammonia in the brain is detoxified to form? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutamine

 

First Line of Defense (Trapping of Ammonia) - Being highly toxic, ammonia should be eliminated or detoxified, as and when it is formed. Even very minute quantity of ammonia may produce toxicity in central nervous system. But, ammonia is always produced by almost all cells, including neurons. The intracellular ammonia is immediately trapped by glutamic acid to form glutamine, especially in brain cells. The glutamine is then transported to liver, where the reaction is reversed by the enzyme glutaminase. The ammonia thus generated is immediately detoxified into urea. Aspartic acid may also undergo similar reaction to form asparagine.

 

 

Ammonia trapping as glutamine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urea: Urea is the primary form of nitrogen excretion in the liver, but it is not the form in which ammonia is detoxified in the brain.

 

Option C. Ammonium ions: Ammonium ions can be a form of ammonia detoxification in the kidney, but not the primary method in the brain.

 

Option D. Alanine: Alanine plays a role in transporting ammonia from muscle to the liver, but it is not the primary detoxification product in the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the brain, ammonia is detoxified by converting it to glutamine, which is then transported to the liver for further detoxification into urea.

choices.text: Conventional PCR with Restriction Fragment Length pair technique
RT-PCR followed by Real time PCR

questions.text: Which of the following is more appropriate for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genome?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RTPCR followed by Real time PCR

 

RT-PCR followed by Real time PCR

 

To quantitatively analyze viral RNA genomes, two key processes are required:

 

  1. Reverse Transcription (RT): Viral RNA must first be converted into complementary DNA (cDNA) because PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) can only amplify DNA. This is done using Reverse Transcriptase, hence RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription PCR).
  2. Quantification using Real Time PCR (qPCR): Once the cDNA is synthesized, Real-Time PCR is used to quantify the amount of target nucleic acid in real time using fluorescent markers.

 

 

Thus, for quantitative analysis of viral RNA:
 

  • First step ‚Üí RT-PCR
  • Second step ‚Üí Real-Time PCR (qPCR)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Real Time PCR: This refers to quantification but only works with DNA, not directly with RNA. Without the reverse transcription step, it cannot quantify viral RNA.
 

Option B. Conventional PCR with RFLP: This is qualitative and used for genotyping or mutation detection, not quantitative analysis.
 

Option C. RT-PCR: RT-PCR alone allows detection of RNA (qualitative), but not quantification unless combined with Real-Time PCR.

 

Educational Objective:


RT PCR followed by Real-time PCR is the most appropriate technique for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genomes, allowing real-time monitoring and quantification of viral RNA load.

questions.text: An infant present with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following is accumulated in the brain in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Long chain fatty acid

 

Long-chain fatty acids are the substances that accumulate in the brain of individuals with cerebrohepatorenal syndrome, contributing to the neurological symptoms such as hypotonia and seizures. This accumulation disrupts normal brain function and leads to the characteristic clinical features of the syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose: Glucose is a normal energy source for the brain and is not typically accumulated in the brain in this syndrome.

 

Option C. Lactic acid: While lactic acid can accumulate in some metabolic disorders, it is not the primary substance that accumulates in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome.

 

Option D. Triglycerides: Triglycerides are a form of fat storage and are not typically accumulated in the brain in this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome or Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome is due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA). Peroxisomal enzymes are produced; but their entry into peroxisome is denied. This leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA. Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes profound neurologic impairment and death in childhood.

questions.text: A paint factory worker working since 20 years complains of joint pain, insomnia, fatigue, constipation, headache. He is found to have anemia. Enzyme affected is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ferrochelatase

 

This enzyme is crucial in the final step of heme synthesis, where it inserts iron into protoporphyrin to form heme. In lead poisoning, ferrochelatase is inhibited, leading to decreased heme production, increased ALA production, and symptoms such as anemia, fatigue, and other neurological symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase: This enzyme is involved in heme synthesis. Lead poisoning can disrupt heme synthesis, but Uroporphyrinogen III synthase is not the primary enzyme affected.

 

Option B. Uroporphyrinogen I Synthase: Similar to Uroporphyrinogen III synthase, this enzyme is involved in heme synthesis. Lead poisoning can disrupt heme synthesis, but Uroporphyrinogen I Synthase is not the primary enzyme affected.

 

Option C. ALA synthase (Aminolevulinic acid synthase): It is a key enzyme in the heme synthesis pathway. Lead poisoning increase activity of ALA synthase. In lead poisoning, product inhibition by heme is  reduced leading to the accumulation of ALA and its precursor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The reference of paint factory worker indicates that it is a case of lead poisoning. Lead affects two enzymes of Heme synthesis pathway:

 

  1. PBG synthase (another name ALA dehydratase)
  2. Ferrochelatase (last enzyme of heme synthesis and adds Fe to its substrate)

 

The defect in any of these enzymes will lead to decrease in haem synthesis resulting in anemia. So, the answer in this case is Ferrochelatase.

 

Reference: Harper‚Äôs 31st ed/pg- 306-307

questions.text: A patient with glycogen storage disease has impaired glucose sensing in pancreatic beta cells. Which glucose transporter defect best explains this? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glut 2

 

GLUT2 is a low-affinity, high-capacity glucose transporter essential for glucose sensing in pancreatic beta cells. It's unique among glucose transporters as it allows rapid equilibration of glucose across the cell membrane, enabling beta cells to sense blood glucose levels and regulate insulin secretion accordingly. Defects in GLUT2 impair this glucose sensing mechanism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GLUT1: While important for basal glucose uptake in many tissues, especially the brain, it's not involved in pancreatic glucose sensing.

 

Option C. GLUT3: This high-affinity transporter is primarily expressed in neurons and isn't involved in pancreatic beta cell function.

 

Option D. GLUT4: Although insulin-sensitive and important for glucose uptake in muscle and adipose tissue, it doesn't play a role in pancreatic glucose sensing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand that:

  1. GLUT2's unique properties (low affinity, high capacity) make it ideal for glucose sensing
  2. It's essential for beta cell function and glucose-stimulated insulin secretion
  3. This differs from GLUT4 which responds to insulin rather than sensing glucose
  4. Different GLUT transporters have specific tissue distributions and functions based on their kinetic properties

choices.text: White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.text: An infant presented to the OPD with a history of vomiting and poor feeding. Musty odor is present in the baby's sweat and urine. Guthrie test was done and it was found to be positive. All are true regarding this disease except? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

 

The given clinical history is suggesting a most probable diagnosis of phenylketonuria (PKU)

Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase is the cause for this disease.

 

Biochemical Abnormalities:

  1. Phenylalanine cannot be converted to tyrosine. So, phenylalanine accumulates. Phenylalanine level in blood is elevated.
  2. So alternate minor pathways are opened. Phenylketone (phenylpyruvate), phenyllactate and phenylacetate are excreted in urine.

 

Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:

  1. The classical PKU child is mentally retarded with an IQ of 50.
  2. Agitation, hyperactivity, tremors and convulsions are often manifested. This may be because phenylalanine interferes with neurotransmitter synthesis.
  3. The child often has hypopigmentation, explained by the inhibition of tyrosinase.
  4. Phenyl acetic acid in sweat may lead to mousy body odor.

 

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  1. Blood phenylalanine: Normal level is 1 mg/dL. In PKU, the level is >20 mg/dL. This may be demonstrated by chromatography. Tandem mass spectroscopy is the most reliable test; but is costly.
  2. Guthrie test is a rapid screening test - Certain strains of Bacillus subtilis need phenylalanine as an essential growth factor. Bacteria cannot grow in a medium devoid of phenylalanine. Bacterial growth is proportional to the phenylalanine content in the patient‚Äôs blood.
  3. Ferric chloride test: Urine of the patient contains phenylketones about 500‚Äì3000 mg/day. This could be detected by adding a drop of ferric chloride to the urine. A transient blue-green color is a positive test. But this is a less reliable test.
  4. DNA probes are now available to diagnose the defects in phenylalanine hydroxylase and dihydrobiopterin reductase.

 

Treatment:

  1. Early detection is very important. About 5 units of IQ are lost for each 10-week delay in starting the treatment.
  2. The treatment is to provide a diet containing low phenylalanine (10‚Äì20 mg/kg body weight per day)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme defect: True: This is the primary defect in PKU, leading to elevated phenylalanine levels.

 

Option C. Phenylacetate positive in urine: True: Phenylacetate, a metabolite of phenylalanine, is found in the urine of patients with PKU.

 

Option D. Mental retardation is present: True: Without early treatment, children with PKU often suffer from severe mental retardation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PKU is characterized by a deficiency in phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to elevated phenylalanine levels and its metabolites, which cause neurological symptoms, hypopigmentation, and a musty odor. Early detection and dietary management are crucial for preventing severe mental retardation.

questions.text: A patient presented with bilateral symmetrical hyperpigmented scaly lesions on sun-exposed areas, along with diarrhea and dementia. What is the diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pellagra

 

Pellagra, caused by niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency, presents with the classical triad of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia ("3 D's"). The dermatitis is characteristically bilateral and symmetric, affecting sun-exposed areas. The skin becomes rough, scaly, and hyperpigmented. This presentation differs from phrynoderma's follicular hyperkeratosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Darier's disease: This genetic condition causes greasy, warty papules in seborrheic areas but lacks the systemic manifestations (diarrhea, dementia) and doesn't show photosensitivity.

 

Option B. Phrynoderma: While also a nutritional deficiency (Vitamin A), it presents with follicular hyperkeratosis primarily on extensor surfaces without systemic involvement.

 

Option D. Acrodermatitis enteropathica: This zinc deficiency condition presents with periorificial and acral dermatitis, but typically affects infants and lacks the characteristic photosensitivity and neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand that:

  1. Pellagra presents with the classic triad of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia
  2. The dermatitis is photosensitive and symmetrical
  3. This helps differentiate it from other nutritional deficiency dermatoses
  4. The systemic involvement (GI and neurological) is key to diagnosis

choices.text: Factors II, VII, IX, and X

questions.text: Which of the following zymogens requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factors II, VII, IX, and X

 

Clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X are zymogens of serine proteases that contain glutamic acid residues. These residues undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation via gamma-glutamyl carboxylase to form gamma-carboxy glutamic acid residues. This enables them to bind calcium ions (Ca2+), which is necessary for their activation and subsequent blood clot formation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factors II, VIII, IX, X: Factor VIII is not a zymogen that requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. It is involved in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation but does not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Option C. Factors II, VII, IX, XI: Factor XI is not a zymogen that requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. It is activated by thrombin and does not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Option D. Factors II, VIII, X, XI: Neither Factor VIII nor Factor XI are zymogens that require gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. They do not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zymogens are the proprotein form of enzymes (proenzymes) that require proteolytic activation to carry out their function.

 

Inactive form of vitamin K acts as a cofactor in the post-synthetic modification of these zymogens and their activation. This inactive form of vitamin K is recycled back from its oxidized form by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which can be inhibited by warfarin or liver failure.

choices.text: It does not depend on the macronutrients

questions.text: Which of the following is Thermogenic food? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High protein diet

 

Increased heat production or increased metabolic rate following the intake of food is called as thermogenic effect of food or diet-induced thermogenesis or specific dynamic action (SDA) of food (non-shivering thermogenesis).

 

Part of this is due to the expenditure of energy for digestion; absorption and active transport of products of the digestion. Another reason for this expenditure of energy is that reserve materials, such as glycogen, triacyl glycerol, protein, etc. are synthesized from small molecules available after digestion.

 

A high protein diet leads to higher protein turnover resulting in increased diet induced thermogenesis.

 

The values of SDA are: for proteins 30%, for lipids 15%, and for carbohydrates 5%. This means that out of every 100 grams of proteins consumed, the energy available for doing useful work is 30% less than the calculated value.

Thermogenesis results from the presence of an uncoupling protein, thermogenin, in the inner mitochondrial membrane.

 

It is a common experience that during hot weather following the consumption of a protein rich meal, one feels hot and humid for a while. On the other hand, in cold weather, the same would provide a comfortable feeling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High fat diet: While fats do contribute to thermogenesis, their specific dynamic action (SDA) is lower (15%) compared to proteins (30%).

 

Option B. It does not depend on the macronutrients: This statement is incorrect, as the thermogenic effect of food does depend on the type of macronutrient consumed.

 

Option D. High carbohydrate diet: Carbohydrates have a lower thermogenic effect (5%) compared to proteins (30%).

 

Educational Objective:

 

A high protein diet has the highest thermogenic effect compared to fats and carbohydrates, leading to increased energy expenditure during digestion and metabolism.

questions.text: Liver produces KB but cannot use KB due to absence of which enzyme:  (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thiophorase

 

The liver lacks the enzyme thiophorase (succinyl-CoA:3-ketoacid CoA transferase) necessary to utilize the ketone bodies it produces. This enzyme is required to convert acetoacetate into acetoacetyl-CoA, which can then be further metabolized into two molecules of acetyl-CoA. Acetyl-CoA is a central molecule in energy metabolism and can enter the citric acid cycle (also known as the Kreb‚Äôs cycle) to produce ATP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiolase: It is the common enzyme of Ketone body synthesis and KB utilization.

 

Option C. HMG CoA synthase: HMG CoA synthase is RLE of ketone bodies synthesis in the liver. It is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA (HMG-CoA), a precursor molecule in the production of cholesterol and ketone bodies. However, the absence of HMG CoA synthase would impact the overall synthesis of ketone bodies rather than their utilization.

 

Option D. HMG CoA reductase: HMG CoA reductase is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of mevalonate, which is a precursor molecule in the production of cholesterol. However, the absence of HMG CoA reductase in the liver would not directly affect the utilization of ketone bodies. It would primarily impact the synthesis of cholesterol and other downstream products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The liver plays a crucial role in ketone body metabolism. During periods of prolonged fasting or low carbohydrate intake, the liver produces ketone bodies (acetoacetate and Œ≤-hydroxybutyrate) through a process called ketogenesis. These ketone bodies are then released into the bloodstream and can be used as an alternative fuel source by various tissues, including the brain, heart, and skeletal muscles.

questions.text: A bodybuilder starts eating raw eggs for protein. He starts to develop fatigue on moderate exercise. The doctor prescribes a vitamin. Which enzyme is deficient in him? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pyruvate Carboxylase

 

Raw eggs contain a protein called avidin, which binds to biotin and prevents its absorption in the intestine. Biotin is a vital coenzyme for several carboxylase enzymes, including pyruvate carboxylase. When biotin is deficient, these enzymes cannot function properly, leading to symptoms such as fatigue, particularly during moderate exercise.

 

Mechanism:

  • Avidin in Raw Eggs: Binds strongly to biotin, preventing its absorption and leading to biotin deficiency.
  • Pyruvate Carboxylase Deficiency: Results in impaired gluconeogenesis and energy production, causing fatigue during exercise.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 Phosphate:

  • Function: Involved in glycogenolysis and the pentose phosphate pathway.
  • Relevance: Not related to biotin deficiency or the symptoms described.

 

Option C. PEPCK (Phosphoenolpyruvate Carboxykinase):

  • Function: Catalyzes the conversion of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate in gluconeogenesis.
  • Relevance: Although involved in gluconeogenesis, its activity is not directly dependent on biotin.

 

Option D. Glycogen Phosphorylase:

  • Function: Breaks down glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate in glycogenolysis.
  • Relevance: Not related to biotin deficiency or the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eating raw eggs can lead to biotin deficiency due to avidin binding, resulting in a deficiency of pyruvate carboxylase. This enzyme deficiency impairs gluconeogenesis, causing fatigue during exercise. Supplementing biotin can correct the deficiency and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: Diarrhoea by cholera toxin involves which receptors:(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GM1 ganglioside receptor

 

Cholera toxin binds specifically to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells. This binding is the initial step in the pathogenesis of cholera. The toxin's B subunits bind to GM1 gangliosides, facilitating the entry of the A subunit into the cells. The A subunit then activates adenylate cyclase, leading to increased cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels and subsequent chloride and water secretion, causing diarrhea.


 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GD-1b Ganglioside Receptor: The GD-1b ganglioside receptor is not the target for cholera toxin. This receptor has other physiological roles in the body and is not primarily associated with the mechanism of cholera toxin-induced diarrhea.

 

Option C. GM2 Ganglioside Receptor: GM2 ganglioside receptors are not involved in the mechanism of action of cholera toxin. They have different functions and are not known to interact with cholera toxin in the pathogenesis of diarrhea.

 

Option D. GM3 Ganglioside Receptor: While GM3 ganglioside is a component of cell membranes, it is not the receptor that cholera toxin binds to. The specific interaction between cholera toxin and GM1 gangliosides is critical for the toxin's effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cholera toxin, produced by Vibrio cholerae, causes diarrhea by binding to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells. The binding of cholera toxin to GM1 facilitates its entry into the cells, where it exerts its toxic effects by activating adenylate cyclase and increasing intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP). Elevated cAMP levels lead to the secretion of chloride ions and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in watery diarrhea characteristic of cholera.

 

Ref: Harper‚Äôs Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 212

questions.text: Which of the following site does the restriction enzyme act when RFLP is used in-order to identify the five different species of staphylococci in a surgical ICU? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GATATC- CTATAG

 

Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP) is a difference in homologous DNA sequences that can be detected by the presence of fragments of different lengths after digestion of the DNA samples in question with specific restriction endonucleases.

 

Restriction endonucleases have specific recognition sites where they cut the DNA. These enzymes recognize specific sequence with palindrome arrangement. These are also called inverted repeat sequences, which means the nucleotide sequence in 5‚Ä≤ to 3‚Ä≤ direction is the same in both strands.

 

Option B. is a palindromic sequence, hence the correct the answer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: ATGGAC ‚Äì TACGTG 

 

  • This is not a palindrome.
  • 5'-ATGGAC
    3'-TACCTG 

 

Option C: TAGATA ‚Äì ATCTAT 

 

  • Not a palindrome.
  • 5'-TAGATA
    3'-ATCTAT

 

Option D: AATATA ‚Äì TATAAT 

 

  • 5'-AATATA
    3'-TATAAT
  • Not a palindrome either. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In RFLP, restriction enzymes recognize and cut at palindromic sequences in DNA. The palindromic sequence GATATC-CTATAG is a correct recognition site for these enzymes, making it crucial for identifying different species, such as staphylococci in a surgical ICU.

questions.text: RNAi acts through? (INICET May 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Knock down

 

Explanation:

 

Gene knock down is when function of the gene present is suppressed by inhibiting or degrading the target mRNA so that it cannot form its protein. This is also known as post transcriptional gene silencing or RNA interference (RNAi). This is mediated by micro RNA (miRNA) or small interfering RNA (siRNA) which are small 20-27 nucleotides long non-coding RNAs. miRNA based RNAi involves the uses of three enzymes DROSHA, PASHA and DICER.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knock out: This involves removing or taking a gene out, resulting in a complete loss of gene function.

 

Option C. Knock in: This involves inserting a gene into a specific location within the genome.

 

Option D. Knock up: This term is not used in the context of gene manipulation.

 

Educational Objective:


RNA interference (RNAi) acts through gene knock down by suppressing the function of a gene via degradation or inhibition of its target mRNA, preventing protein formation.

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/p 346-348

questions.text: In which of the genetic material, Number of Adenine will not be equal to that of Thymine:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HIV

 

The questions is related to genetic material of different organisms or viruses and their base pairing rules. In DNA, adenine (A) always pairs with thymine (T), and cytosine (C) always pairs with guanine (G). However, in RNA, which is the genetic material of some viruses like HIV, thymine is replaced by uracil (U) in base pairing. So, in RNA, adenine pairs with uracil.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E. coli (Escherichia coli): E. coli is a bacterium, and its genetic material is DNA. In DNA, adenine pairs with thymine, so the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Option B. Mitochondrial DNA of humans: Mitochondrial DNA is also composed of DNA, and in DNA, adenine pairs with thymine. Therefore, the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Option D. Herpes virus: Herpes viruses have dsDNA as their genetic material, so adenine pairs with thymine in their DNA. Thus, the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) is a retrovirus with RNA as its genetic material. In RNA, adenine pairs with uracil. So, the number of adenine will not be equal to that of thymine.

choices.text: Every acidic amino acid is essential.
Every basic amino acid is essential.
Every neutral amino acid is essential.
None of the statements are correct.

questions.text: Which one of the following assertions is correct? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) None of the statements are correct

 

Explanation:

 

The classification of amino acids as essential or non-essential is independent of their acidic, basic, or neutral properties. Essential amino acids cannot be synthesized in sufficient amounts by humans and must be obtained from the diet.

 

Looking at specific examples:

 

  • Acidic amino acids (aspartate and glutamate) are non-essential
  • Basic amino acids include arginine (semi-essential), lysine (essential), and histidine (semi-essential)
  • Neutral amino acids include both essential (valine, leucine, isoleucine) and non-essential (alanine, glycine) amino acids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Every acidic amino acid is essential: This is incorrect. Acidic amino acids (glutamate and aspartate) are both non-essential as they can be synthesized from TCA cycle intermediates.

 

Option B. Every basic amino acid is essential: This is incorrect. While lysine is essential, arginine is semi-essential (some amount can be made in the body), and histidine is semi-essential (essential in children but not in adults).

 

Option C. Every neutral amino acid is essential: This is incorrect. Many neutral amino acids like alanine, serine, glycine, and proline are non-essential, while others like leucine and isoleucine are essential.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Amino acid classification by chemical property (acidic, basic, neutral) has no correlation with their nutritional classification (essential vs non-essential), with both essential and non-essential amino acids occurring across all chemical categories.

questions.text: Which is not a product of heme catabolism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aminolaevulinic acid

 

Heme catabolism is the process by which the heme portion of hemoglobin is broken down. This process begins with the degradation of heme into biliverdin, which is subsequently reduced to bilirubin. This bilirubin is further processed into conjugated bilirubin, urobilinogen, and stercobilinogen. In addition to these products, heme catabolism also generates carbon monoxide and ferrous ion (Fe¬≤‚Å∫).

 

Aminolaevulinic acid, on the other hand, is not a product of heme catabolism but is instead an important precursor in the synthesis of heme. It is formed in the first step of heme synthesis, where succinyl-CoA and glycine combine under the action of the enzyme aminolaevulinic acid synthase.

 

Therefore, while ferrous ion, biliverdin, and carbon monoxide are products of heme catabolism, aminolaevulinic acid is involved in heme synthesis and not in its breakdown.
