Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferrous ion: This is indeed a product of heme catabolism, as iron is released during the breakdown of the heme group.

 

Option C. Biliverdin: Biliverdin is one of the direct products of heme degradation, and it is subsequently reduced to bilirubin.

 

Option D. Carbon monoxide: This is another product of heme catabolism, and notably, heme catabolism is the only process in the human body where carbon monoxide is produced endogenously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aminolaevulinic acid is a precursor in the synthesis of heme, not a product of its catabolism.

questions.text: During periods of starvation, which of the following tissues primarily utilizes ketone bodies as an energy source? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brain

 

Explanation:

 

The brain is the primary tissue that utilizes ketone bodies as an energy source during starvation. When glucose levels are low during prolonged fasting or starvation, the brain shifts from relying on glucose to using ketone bodies (acetoacetate and Œ≤-hydroxybutyrate) as its main fuel source. The brain can derive up to 75% of its energy requirements from ketone bodies during prolonged starvation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erythrocytes: Erythrocytes (red blood cells) lack mitochondria and therefore cannot utilize ketone bodies, which require mitochondrial metabolism. They rely exclusively on glucose via glycolysis for their energy needs.

 

Option C. Liver: The liver is the main site of ketone body production but cannot utilize ketone bodies itself because it lacks the enzyme thiophorase, which is necessary for ketone body utilization.

 

Option D. All of the above: This is incorrect because both erythrocytes and liver cannot utilize ketone bodies as explained above.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

During starvation, the brain adapts to use ketone bodies as an alternative fuel source when glucose is limited, while the liver produces but cannot use ketone bodies, and erythrocytes remain dependent on glucose metabolism.

choices.text: E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate Decarboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase
E1: Pyruvate carboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

questions.text: This multienzyme complex converts Pyruvate to Acetyl CoA. Identify E1 and E2: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

 

Explanation:

 

The provided images depict the components and functioning of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, a key multienzyme complex in the metabolic pathway that converts pyruvate into acetyl-CoA, an essential step linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle. This complex requires vitamins B1, B2, B3, B5, and lipoic acid as cofactors.

 

Table: Components of PDH complex and their roles

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyruvate Decarboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as Pyruvate Decarboxylase is not involved in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in this context, and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase is the E3 component of the complex.

 

Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase: Incorrect because Pyruvate carboxylase is involved in a different metabolic pathway (gluconeogenesis), not in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.

 

Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as the second enzyme is E3 in this complex, not E2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 162

questions.text: Identify the vitamin deficiency: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

 

Vitamin D The image show Bowing of the legs, a condition known as bowlegs or genu varum, is commonly associated with Vitamin D deficiency, especially in children. Vitamin D plays a crucial role in the regulation of calcium and phosphorus, essential minerals for bone health. Deficiency of Vitamin D can lead to improper mineralization of bones, resulting in deformities such as bowing of the legs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is not typically associated with bowing of the legs. However, severe vitamin A deficiency cause night blindness and other eye menifestations.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Vitamin B3 deficiency can cause pellagra, which involves skin, gastrointestinal, and neurological symptoms. It is not directly linked to bowing of the legs.

 

Option D. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Vitamin B1 deficiency can lead to beriberi, a condition that primarily affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems. It is not a common cause of bowing of the legs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D

questions.text: A 35-year-old Farmer on maize diet with diarrhoea, dementia, and dermatitis. Which Vitamin is deficient in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Niacin

 

  • Niacin deficiency, specifically pellagra, is characterized by the "3 Ds": dermatitis (skin changes), diarrhea (digestive symptoms), and dementia (neurological symptoms). The symptoms described in the patient match those of pellagra, making niacin deficiency the likely cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine deficiency, also known as beriberi, primarily manifests as neurological and cardiovascular symptoms. It is not associated with dermatitis and diarrhea, which are prominent features of pellagra.

 

Option B. Riboflavin: Riboflavin deficiency, also known as ariboflavinosis, can lead to various symptoms, including sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, and inflammation and redness of the tongue (magenta tongue). While it shares some symptoms with pellagra, such as mucous membrane changes, it does not typically cause dementia and diarrhea.

 

Option D. Pyridoxine: Pyridoxine deficiency, also known as vitamin B6 deficiency, can lead to neurological symptoms but does not typically cause dermatitis or diarrhea. It is not the primary deficiency associated with the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The major protein of Maize, ‚ÄúZein‚Äù lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Pellagra is characterized by 3Ds i.e. diarrhoea, dementia and dermatitis. Death and delirium and depression can also occur.

 

Pellagra can also be caused due to Isoniazid therapy as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra.

 

Thiamine (B1) deficiency leads to Beri-Beri. CNS and CVS are affected in dry Beri-Beri and wet Beri-Beri respectively.

 

Main symptoms of Riboflavin deficiency are Cheilosis, Glossitis and Corneal vascularization.

 

Pyridoxine deficiency cause anemia (microcytic, hypochromic) and seizures in infants.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 534-535

questions.text: In the shown Indian thali, which food item marked in the image is the best source of riboflavin (Vitamin B2)? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

The item marked 'C' appears to be curd/yogurt, which is one of the richest dietary sources of riboflavin (Vitamin B2). Dairy products are excellent sources of riboflavin, with fermented dairy products like yogurt having particularly high concentrations due to bacterial synthesis during fermentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Rice While rice contains some B vitamins, it is not a significant source of riboflavin, especially when polished.

 

Option B: This appears to be a curry dish which, while nutritious, is not a primary source of riboflavin.

 

Option D: These appear to be vegetables/salad items which contain some riboflavin but in much lower quantities compared to dairy products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand that:

  1. Dairy products, especially fermented ones like yogurt, are excellent sources of riboflavin
  2. The bacterial fermentation process in yogurt can increase riboflavin content
  3. While many foods contain small amounts of riboflavin, dairy products are among the richest dietary sources
  4. This differs from thiamine (B1) which is primarily found in whole grains and legumes

questions.text: Which amino acid is not used for synthesis of hormones?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glycine

 

Glycine is an amino acid that does not directly participate in the synthesis of hormones. While glycine is an important amino acid involved in many biological processes, including the synthesis of proteins, it is not a precursor for hormone synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine: Tyrosine is a precursor for the synthesis of several important hormones, including thyroid hormones (thyroxine and triiodothyronine), catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine), and melanin.

 

Option B. Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine is converted into tyrosine in the body and, as a result, indirectly contributes to hormone synthesis. Tyrosine, derived from phenylalanine, is then used for the synthesis of various hormones.

 

Option C. Tryptophan: Tryptophan is an essential amino acid that serves as a precursor for the synthesis of serotonin and melatonin, both of which are important hormones involved in regulating mood, sleep, and other physiological processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tyrosine, phenylalanine, and tryptophan are all aromatic amino acids that serve as building blocks for the synthesis of various hormones.

questions.text: Wobble hypothesis is due to which property of the codon?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Degeneracy

 

  • The wobble hypothesis is primarily due to the degeneracy of the genetic code. Degeneracy means that multiple codons can code for the same amino acid. The third position of the codon (the wobble position) is less constrained and allows for some variation in the base pairing, which accommodates the degeneracy in the genetic code.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ambiguity: Ambiguity is not a property of the codon but rather a state of uncertainty or multiple interpretations. In the genetic code, codons are specific and not ambiguous in their assignment to amino acids.

 

Option C. Universality: Universality refers to the fact that the genetic code is nearly identical in all living organisms. While universality is an important property of the genetic code, it is not directly related to the wobble hypothesis.

 

Option D. Commaless: "Commaless" is not a recognized property related to the codon or the wobble hypothesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The wobble hypothesis is primarily due to the degeneracy of the genetic code, allowing multiple codons to code for the same amino acid, with variation in the third (wobble) position of the codon.

 

Wobble bases

 

3rd base of the codon on mRNA and 1st base of anticodon on tRNA in 5‚Äô to 3‚Äô direction are wobble positions.

 

 

Wobble hypothesis says that for binding between bases present in these positions, some imprecision is allowed. i.e. one base in anticodon can bind with various bases of codon. This is also called as degeneracy of codon i.e. There is more than one codon for one amino acid. So, Wobble hypothesis is due to degeneracy of codons.

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent kidney stones. The microscopic examination of the urine specimen is shown below. Which of the following is not seen in the urine of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cysteine

 

  • Cystine is the oxidized dimer form of cysteine (two cysteine molecules joined by a disulfide bond).
  • Cystine, not cysteine, is excreted in urine and precipitates to form stones.
  • Therefore, cysteine is not typically found in the urine of cystinuric patients in significant amounts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arginine: Arginine is an amino acid and is not typically associated with kidney stone formation. It is usually found in the urine.

 

Option B. Lysine: Lysine is another amino acid and is not commonly linked to kidney stone formation. It is typically present in the urine.

 

Option C. Cystine: Cystine is an amino acid that is known to form cystine stones, a type of kidney stone. Therefore, cystine can be found in the urine of patients with cystine stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystinuria: Cystinuria is one of the inborn errors of metabolism included in the Garrod‚Äôs tetrad. It is an autosomal recessive condition.

 

The disorder is attributed to the deficiency in transport of amino acids Signs and symptoms include:

 

  1. Abnormal excretion of cystine and to a lesser extent lysine, ornithine and arginine. Hence the condition is also called Cystine-lysinuria.
  2. Crystalluria and calculi formation. In acidic pH, cystine crystals are formed in urine
  3. Obstructive uropathy, which may lead to renal insufficiency
  4. Cyanide-Nitroprusside Test is a screening test. Urine is made alkaline with ammonium hydroxide and sodium cyanide is added. Cystine, if present, is reduced to cysteine. Then add sodium nitroprusside to get a magenta-red colored complex. Specific aminoaciduria may be confirmed by chromatography.
  5. Treatment is to increase urinary volume by increasing fluid intake. Solubility of cystine is increased by alkalinization of urine by giving sodium bicarbonate.

questions.text: What would be the respiratory quotient if someone is on an exclusive carbohydrate diet? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1

 

The respiratory quotient (RQ) is defined as the ratio of the volume of CO2 produced to the volume of O2 consumed during metabolism. The RQ value varies depending on the type of substrate being metabolized.

 

Respiratory Quotient Values of Carbohydrates:

 

The RQ for carbohydrates is 1. This is because the metabolism of carbohydrates involves the complete oxidation of glucose, which produces CO2 and consumes O2 in a 1:1 ratio. The equation for glucose oxidation is:

 

When an individual is on an exclusive carbohydrate diet, the metabolism of carbohydrates is the primary source of energy, leading to an RQ value of 1. In conditions like diabetes mellitus, where the utilization of carbohydrates is impaired and fat metabolism predominates, the RQ falls below 1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory quotient (RQ) is defined as the ratio of volume of CO2 produced in L/g to the oxygen consumed in L/g.

questions.text: The illustration below shows alternative splicing of a gene which has intron segments 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. It yields two products A and B, by the action of different promoters. You are provided with the promoters W, X, Y, and Z, each of which binds to a different segment as shown below and acts in the marked direction. Which of the following promoters will you use to get product A? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. W Y

 

Explanation:

 

A promoter is a region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate

transcription of that gene. In the case of this question, product A is formed by including specific

segments and excluding others through the process of alternative splicing.

 

  • Sequence A consists of segments 1, 3, 4, and 5.
    • Promoter W Required for segment 1.
    • Promoter Y Required for segments 3, 4, and 5.
    • Segment 2 is excluded during alternative splicing.

 

Thus, the combination of Promoters W and Y will result in the production of sequence A by including

the correct segments and excluding segment 2.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a (W, X, Y): This combination Required Promoter X, for segment 2, but it

    is unnecessary since W and Y alone are sufficient to yield product A.

  • Option b (W, Z): Promoter Z does not include segments 3, making this option incorrect for generating product A.
  • Option c (WX): Promoters W and X are insufficient because they do not include segments 3, 4, and 5, which are essential for product A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A promoter is a region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate

transcription of that gene.

 

Using promoters W, Y will yield product A by including segments 1, 3, 4, and 5 and removing segment 2 through alternative splicing.

questions.text: Brunt sugar smell of urine is due to the defect of? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase

 

Explanation:

 

  • Burnt sugar-like odour is a characteristic feature of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) which occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched chain Keto-acid dehydrogenase/decarboxylase.
  • It results in a defect in oxidative phosphorylation and catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) Valine/Isoleucine/leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in urine. There is also mental retardation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase leads to phenylketonuria (PKU), which is characterized by a mousy or musty odor due to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites.

 

Option B. Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase: Deficiency of isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase causes isovaleric acidemia, which is associated with a rancid, cheesy, or sweaty feet odor due to the accumulation of isovaleric acid.

 

Option C. Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase: Deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase leads to tyrosinemia type I, which is characterized by a boiled cabbage or rotten mushrooms odor due to the accumulation of tyrosine and its metabolites.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Aimed to catalog human genetic variation
Created a public database of variants

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the 1000 Genomes Project? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Included populations from single continent

 

This is false. The 1000 Genomes Project included populations from multiple continents (Africa, Europe, Asia, and the Americas) to create a comprehensive catalog of human genetic variation across diverse populations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aimed to catalog human genetic variation: True - The project's primary goal was to create a detailed catalog of human genetic variation, including common and rare variants.

 

Option C. Used next-generation sequencing technologies: True - The project utilized various next-generation sequencing methods, including whole-genome sequencing and exome sequencing.

 

Option D. Created a public database of variants: True - All data was made freely available through public databases, allowing researchers worldwide to access and use the information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand key features of the 1000 Genomes Project:

  1. It was a comprehensive effort to catalog global human genetic variation
  2. Included diverse populations from multiple continents
  3. Used modern sequencing technologies
  4. Made data publicly available
  5. Differed from the Human Genome Project by focusing on population-level variation rather than creating a single reference genome
